- **Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF):** A new user interface subsystem and API based on XAML markup language, utilizing 3D computer graphics hardware and Direct3D technologies.

- **Windows Communication Foundation (WCF):** A service-oriented messaging system that allows programs to interoperate locally or remotely, similar to web services.

- **Windows CardSpace:** A software component that securely stores a person's digital identities and provides a unified interface for choosing the identity for a particular transaction, such as logging into a website.

These components were designed to enhance the development of Windows applications by providing advanced features for user interfaces, communication, workflows, and identity management.

Bullet drop in Call of Duty.search_query: When was bullet drop introduced in Call of Duty multiplayer?
Bullet drop in Call of Duty.evidence:
Bullet drop was first introduced in Call of Duty's multiplayer mode during the Black Ops 4 Beta in August 2018. Treyarch developer Tony Flame revealed that the studio was implementing a "mixed ballistics" system, incorporating bullet drop on certain weapons to test and balance gameplay. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/treyarch-dev-reveals-bullet-drop-and-new-ballistics-system-will-be-tested-in-black-ops-4-multiplayer-beta-129626/?utm_source=openai))

Prior to this, the series utilized a hitscan mechanic, where bullets traveled instantly to their target without any drop. The introduction of bullet drop in Black Ops 4 marked a significant shift in the game's mechanics, adding a new layer of realism and requiring players to adjust their aiming strategies, especially at longer distances.

This feature was further expanded in Call of Duty: Modern Warfare (2019), where Infinity Ward incorporated bullet drop and windage into the campaign mode, particularly affecting sniper rifles and designated marksman rifles (DMRs). Art director Joel Emslie explained that players would need to account for bullet trajectory, including drop and wind, when using these weapons. ([dexerto.com](https://www.dexerto.com/call-of-duty/call-of-duty-dev-reveals-how-bullet-drop-will-work-modern-warfare-710625/?utm_source=openai))

In summary, bullet drop was first introduced in Call of Duty's multiplayer with the Black Ops 4 Beta in August 2018, and has since become a standard feature in subsequent titles, enhancing the game's realism and strategic depth.

Southern Ocean (IHO recognition).search_query: When did the IHO define the limits of the Southern Ocean?
Southern Ocean (IHO recognition).evidence:
The International Hydrographic Organization (IHO) first defined the limits of the Southern Ocean in its 1928 publication, *Limits of Oceans and Seas*. This edition delineated the Southern Ocean by land-based boundaries: Antarctica to the south, and the continents of South America, Africa, Australia, and New Zealand to the north. The specific delineation included:

- From Cape Horn in Chile eastward to Cape Agulhas in Africa.
- Then further eastward to the southern coast of mainland Australia to Cape Leeuwin, Western Australia.
- From Cape Leeuwin, the limit followed eastward along the coast of mainland Australia to Cape Otway, Victoria.
- Then southward across Bass Strait to Cape Wickham, King Island, along the west coast of King Island, then south across Bass Strait to Cape Grim, Tasmania.
- The limit then followed the west coast of Tasmania southward to the South East Cape and then went eastward to Broughton Island, New Zealand, before returning to Cape Horn.

In the 1937 second edition, the IHO moved the northern limits of the Southern Ocean southward, extending from Antarctica northward to latitude 40°S between Cape Agulhas in Africa (long. 20°E) and Cape Leeuwin in Western Australia (long. 115°E), and extending to latitude 55°S between Auckland Island of New Zealand (165 or 166°E east) and Cape Horn in South America (67°W).

However, in the 1953 third edition, the IHO omitted the Southern Ocean from its official publication, leaving its definition to local hydrographic offices. The IHO readdressed the question of the Southern Ocean in a survey in 2000. Of its 68 member nations, 28 responded, and all responding members except Argentina agreed to redefine the ocean, reflecting the importance placed by oceanographers on ocean currents. The proposal for the name Southern Ocean won 18 votes, beating the alternative Antarctic Ocean. Half of the votes supported a definition of the ocean's northern limit at the 60th parallel south—with no land interruptions at this latitude—with the other 14 votes cast for other definitions, mostly the 50th parallel south, but a few for as far north as the 35th parallel south. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southern_Ocean?utm_source=openai))

A draft fourth edition of the *Limits of Oceans and Seas* was circulated to IHO member states in August 2002, but it has not been formally adopted due to ongoing discussions and disagreements among member states. As of January 2026, the IHO has not officially recognized the Southern Ocean as a distinct ocean. However, in April 2023, the IHO Assembly approved a resolution recognizing the Southern Ocean as the global sea area surrounding the continent of Antarctica, with its northern limit defined by the parallel of latitude 60°S. This resolution aligns with the previously proposed definition but does not alter the official status of the Southern Ocean within the IHO's publications. ([unstats.un.org](https://unstats.un.org/unsd/ungegn/sessions/4th_session_2025/documents/GEGN.2_2025_157_CRP157_item6c.pdf?utm_source=openai))

In summary, while the IHO first defined the limits of the Southern Ocean in 1928, its official recognition has evolved over time, with the most recent resolution in 2023 acknowledging its existence without altering its official status within the IHO's publications.

The Virgin Islands, comprising the U.S. Virgin Islands (USVI) and the British Virgin Islands (BVI), offer a diverse array of experiences for travelers. Here's a comprehensive guide to help you plan your visit:

**Overview**

- **U.S. Virgin Islands (USVI):** Consist of St. Thomas, St. John, and St. Croix.
- **British Virgin Islands (BVI):** Include Tortola, Virgin Gorda, Anegada, and Jost Van Dyke.

**Key Attractions**

- **St. Thomas (USVI):** Known for its bustling port, shopping, and vibrant nightlife.
- **St. John (USVI):** Home to the Virgin Islands National Park, offering pristine beaches and hiking trails. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virgin_Islands_National_Park?utm_source=openai))
- **St. Croix (USVI):** Offers rich history, including rum distilleries and historical sites.
- **Tortola (BVI):** Features Sage Mountain National Park, the highest point in the Virgin Islands, ideal for hiking. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Sage_National_Park?utm_source=openai))

**Activities**

- **Snorkeling and Diving:** Coki Beach in St. Thomas is renowned for its vibrant marine life and clear waters. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coki_Beach?utm_source=openai))
- **Hiking:** Explore trails in Virgin Islands National Park on St. John and Sage Mountain National Park on Tortola.
- **Cultural Experiences:** Visit local markets, attend festivals, and explore historical sites to immerse yourself in the islands' rich culture.

**Travel Tips**

- **Transportation:** Ferries connect the islands, and taxis are readily available.
- **Currency:** The USVI uses the U.S. Dollar; the BVI uses the East Caribbean Dollar.
- **Weather:** The islands enjoy a tropical climate with warm temperatures year-round.

Blender Geometry Nodes.search_query: When were Geometry Nodes introduced in Blender?
Blender Geometry Nodes.evidence: Geometry Nodes were introduced in Blender 2.92, released in February 2020. This feature allows users to create and manipulate geometry procedurally using a node-based interface, enhancing the flexibility and efficiency of modeling workflows.

Blender 2.92.evidence:
Blender 2.92 was released on February 25, 2021. ([blender.org](https://www.blender.org/download/releases/2-92/?utm_source=openai)) This major update introduced several significant features, including:

- **Geometry Nodes**: A new node-based system for creating and manipulating meshes, allowing for procedural workflows. ([blender.org](https://www.blender.org/download/releases/2-92/?utm_source=openai))

- **Sculpting Enhancements**: Improvements such as the Multires Displacement Smear tool and the ability to edit Grease Pencil strokes as curves. ([blender.org](https://www.blender.org/download/releases/2-92/?utm_source=openai))

- **Physics Simulations**: Introduction of the APIC fluid simulation method, building upon the existing Mantaflow system. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blender_%28software%29?utm_source=openai))

Florence Cathedral dome completion.search_query: When was the Florence Cathedral dome completed?
Florence Cathedral dome completion.evidence:
The dome of Florence Cathedral, known as Brunelleschi's Dome, was completed in 1436. Construction began on August 7, 1420, under the direction of architect Filippo Brunelleschi. The dome was consecrated by Pope Eugene IV on March 25, 1436, marking its official completion. ([duomo.firenze.it](https://duomo.firenze.it/en/opera-magazine/post/4649/on-30-august-1436-the-work-on-brunelleschi-s-dome-was-completed?utm_source=openai))

Brunelleschi's innovative design for the dome was groundbreaking, as it was the first octagonal dome in history to be built without a temporary wooden supporting frame. This engineering marvel remains the largest masonry dome ever constructed. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florence_Cathedral?utm_source=openai))

For a visual exploration of how this architectural feat was achieved, you might find the following video insightful:

[How Was the World's Biggest Dome Built? - Florence Cathedral](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QD3fJphus-o&utm_source=openai)

Vigenère cipher.search_query: When was the Vigenère cipher invented?
Vigenère cipher.evidence: The Vigenère cipher, a method of encrypting alphabetic text, was first described by Italian cryptographer Giovan Battista Bellaso in 1553. ([britannica.com](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Vigenere-cipher?utm_source=openai)) However, it was French cryptographer Blaise de Vigenère who, in 1586, introduced a more advanced version of the cipher, which is why it bears his name. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blaise_de_Vigen%C3%A8re?utm_source=openai))

Fibonacci sequence.search_query: When was the Fibonacci sequence introduced to Western mathematics?
Fibonacci sequence.evidence: The Fibonacci sequence was introduced to Western mathematics in 1202 by the Italian mathematician Leonardo of Pisa, known as Fibonacci. In his book *Liber Abaci* (The Book of Calculation), he presented the sequence as a solution to a problem involving the growth of a population of rabbits. This sequence, where each number is the sum of the two preceding ones, is now known as the Fibonacci sequence.

CSS Grid Layout (Modern Support).search_query: When was CSS Grid supported in Chrome and Firefox?
CSS Grid Layout (Modern Support).evidence:
CSS Grid Layout was introduced in major browsers in 2017:

- **Chrome**: Version 57, released on March 9, 2017. ([web-platform-dx.github.io](https://web-platform-dx.github.io/web-features-explorer/features/grid?utm_source=openai))

- **Firefox**: Version 52, released on March 7, 2017. ([web-platform-dx.github.io](https://web-platform-dx.github.io/web-features-explorer/features/grid?utm_source=openai))

- **Edge**: Version 16, released on October 17, 2017. ([web-platform-dx.github.io](https://web-platform-dx.github.io/web-features-explorer/features/grid?utm_source=openai))

By October 2017, all major browsers supported CSS Grid without vendor prefixes. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CSS_grid_layout?utm_source=openai))

Unprefixed CSS Animation Support.search_query: When did Chrome support unprefixed CSS animations?
Unprefixed CSS Animation Support.evidence: Chrome began supporting unprefixed CSS animations in version 43, released in 2015. ([grokipedia.com](https://grokipedia.com/page/CSS_animations?utm_source=openai)) Prior to this, developers needed to use the `-webkit-` prefix to ensure compatibility with Chrome. The transition to unprefixed CSS animations was part of a broader move towards standardization, with the W3C allowing unprefixed implementations of CSS Transforms, Transitions, and Animations in 2012. ([wired.com](https://www.wired.com/2012/06/w3c-gives-its-blessing-to-prefix-free-css-animations/?utm_source=openai))

Starbucks 2030 waste reduction goal.search_query: When did Starbucks announce its goal to cut waste in half by 2030?
Starbucks 2030 waste reduction goal.evidence:
Starbucks announced its goal to reduce waste by 50% by 2030 on January 21, 2020. This commitment was part of a broader initiative to become a "resource-positive" company, aiming to store more carbon than it emits, eliminate waste, and provide more clean freshwater than it uses. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/emea/stories/2020/starbucks-announces-multi-decade-aspiration-to-become-resource-positive/?utm_source=openai))

To achieve this waste reduction target, Starbucks outlined several strategies, including expanding plant-based menu options, shifting away from single-use packaging, and investing in sustainable farming and forest practices. ([foodbusinessnews.net](https://www.foodbusinessnews.net/articles/15257-starbucks-lays-out-2030-sustainability-targets?utm_source=openai))

In March 2024, Starbucks furthered its environmental commitment by verifying 6,091 Greener Stores across more than 40 markets globally. These stores are designed to advance the company's goal of reducing carbon emissions, water usage, and landfill waste by 50% by 2030. ([about.starbucks.com](https://about.starbucks.com/press/2024/starbucks-announces-6000-greener-stores-worldwide/?utm_source=openai))

Additionally, in April 2024, Starbucks introduced redesigned cold cups that use up to 20% less plastic. This initiative is part of the company's broader sustainability efforts to reduce plastic waste and aligns with its goal to cut waste by 50% by 2030. ([apnews.com](https://apnews.com/article/90f19ce6ff721c7bf900f1447932dcc0?utm_source=openai))

Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' program.search_query: When did Starbucks launch the 'Borrow a Cup' program?
Starbucks 'Borrow a Cup' program.evidence:
Starbucks launched its "Borrow a Cup" program in April 2021, initiating a two-month trial in five Seattle stores. ([foodnetwork.com](https://www.foodnetwork.com/fn-dish/news/starbucks-reusable-cup-program-borrow-a-cup-seattle?utm_source=openai)) This program allowed customers to order beverages in reusable cups, each replacing up to 30 disposable cups. Customers paid a $1 refundable deposit for the reusable cup and could return it at participating stores' contactless kiosks or through a local recycling service. ([geekwire.com](https://www.geekwire.com/2021/starbucks-trying-reusable-cups-cut-waste-teaming-seattle-recycling-startup/?utm_source=openai))

Following the success of the Seattle trial, Starbucks expanded the program to other locations. In January 2022, the company launched the "Borrow a Cup" program at three stores in Singapore, aiming to encourage customers to shift away from single-use cups. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/asia/stories/2022/starbucks-launches-a-reusable-borrow-a-cup-program-at-three-stores-in-singapore/?utm_source=openai)) By November 2022, the program had expanded to 60 stores in Taiwan, with plans to extend coverage to all stores nationwide by the end of 2023. ([stories.starbucks.com](https://stories.starbucks.com/asia/stories/2022/starbucks-offers-borrow-a-cup-program-at-sixty-stores-in-taiwan/?utm_source=openai))

In August 2023, Starbucks further expanded the program to 12 stores in Napa and Petaluma, California, as part of its sustainability efforts. ([sustainabilitymea.com](https://www.sustainabilitymea.com/starbucks-expands-reusable-cup-format-to-12-california-stores-in-sustainability-drive/?utm_source=openai)) By January 2024, Starbucks accepted reusable personal cups at all service points, including drive-thru and mobile orders, supporting the company's goal to reduce waste by 50% by 2030. ([axios.com](https://www.axios.com/2024/01/03/starbucks-reusable-cup-policy-mobile-drive-thru?utm_source=openai))
